anss. L. G. § 291. In simple sentences se refers to the subject of its own clause. In indirect statement (or aocuS. and infin.) if the subject of the dependent is the same as that of the main clause, se must be used (the same rule applies to suus) otherwise eum, eos (for the possessive eius, eorum) must. be used to translate him, them, διο. ‘ He replied that he had not given the book to them, but they to him.’ Ille respondit non se iis sed eos sibi librum dedisse.
